Award.AwardTitle: Texas Tech Noyce Scholars Phase II (TTNS-II)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program, this project addresses the Nation's growing need to recruit and prepare secondary STEM teachers. The project will recruit STEM students from Texas Tech University, as well as from three community colleges and will provide them with effective mentoring, in addition to the pedagogical and discipline-based knowledge they need to teach in the Lubbock area school systems. These well-trained teachers will help close the documented achievement gap in these schools. This project is a partnership among Texas Tech University (TTU), the Lubbock Independent School District, South Plains College, Midland College, and Odessa College. As a Phase II Scholarship and Stipend project, it will apply what was learned during the Phase I Noyce project to enhance the recruitment and mentored retention of talented STEM students into high needs secondary schools in west Texas.

The successful Phase I project supported 37 students. This Phase II project will prepare an additional 16 new teachers. The evaluation of the Phase I project provided knowledge that informed the design and development of the current project. Based on what was learned, the project PI team will recruit students from among community college students, as well as TTU students, and will involve current Noyce scholars in those recruiting efforts. In addition, the project will support the pre-service teachers through group mentoring, which they have found to be more effective.

The Phase II project will encourage the scholars to explore self-determination and will provide Autonomy Support Training from in-service teachers during their internships and classroom placements. These activities will result in a more intentional self-selection for the teaching career and a higher probability of staying with the profession. Research on the features of self-determination and autonomy exploration will generate knowledge on the elements of motivation that may be effective in recruitment of pre-service teachers. The project outcomes will be evaluated through surveys, interviews, document analysis of research reports, and questionnaires. The results of the research and evaluation will inform the recruitment and support of pre-service teachers in programs across the country.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was a Phase 2 Noyce program that was implemented from 2014 to 2019. The program awarded 31 scholarships to Texas Tech STEM students who committed to teaching in high needs schools on completion of their teaching certification. Students were also recruited from partner colleges, namely South Plains College, Midland College, and Odessa College. 

As of November 2019, eighteen (18) scholars have obtained teaching positions. Seven (7) students are completing their degree and teaching certifications while one (1) is pursuing an alternate certification and five (5) have not yet finalized their plans for certification.

The research component of the project was primarily concerned with pre-Noyce recruitment. Initial project investigations focused on whether STEM majors? intrinsic interest in teaching could be increased through engagement in autonomy supportive teaching activities. Undergraduate students from a variety of STEM majors were recruited across the first two summers of funding to serve as tutors and assistants for public school student outreach programs that emphasized autonomy for the STEM majors.  

However, there was limited preservice teaching scholar recruitment success from those program elements, especially in relation to recruitment from the community college partners. Some deficiencies in the approach have been identified and an updated recruitment approach will be implemented in a new Noyce Track I project beginning this year, namely, recruiting students to first serve as Learning Assistants in lower division mathematics classes and using this experience to attract them to the teaching profession. New research was also initiated on factors affecting Noyce teacher retention and this research will continue as part of the new Noyce program.

In general, it was difficult to recruit high school mathematics and science teachers and the program focused more on middle school teacher candidates. The program obtained permission from NSF to designate the Multidisciplinary Studies programs with emphases in mathematics and science as STEM degrees for the purpose of this award. Recruitment from this group was high and over the five year grant period the majority of scholarship awardees were preservice middle school mathematics and science teachers. Awardees represent a high level of diversity where 81% are women, 23% are Hispanic, and 10% are African American.

The Noyce Scholars took mathematics courses designed specifically to develop deep understanding of the mathematics they will teach. The curricula for some of these required mathematics courses have been designed to closely align with state mathematics standards and certification expectations. Pre-service teachers also complete a full year of student teaching to achieve a higher-than-average level of clinical training.

A feature of the program was a special seminar for Noyce scholars. The seminar focused on various aspects of teaching and learning in mathematics. Some scholars? schedules precluded face to face attendance and an online section was also developed. The seminar was very productive in developing cohort unity and mentoring relationships with faculty.

Another feature of the program was to continue the tracking of scholars from a previous Phase 1 Noyce program. That program recruited 23 mathematics majors, seven (7) chemistry majors, one (1) physics major, one (1) engineering major, one (1) interdisciplinary science major as well as three (3) post-baccalaureate candidates with mathematics degrees.  In addition, the program recruited six (6) additional teachers in interdisciplinary or multidisciplinary degrees. The total number of scholarship recipients was 42. Twenty three (23) of the scholars from that award have completed their teaching certification while three more are on target to do so soon. Three of the remaining scholars have done some teaching but it is unclear whether or not they will complete their commitment within the specified time limit.  Three have had extenuating family circumstances that have removed them from teaching for an undetermined amount of time. Finally, there are 10 graduates who are unlikely to fulfill their full teaching requirement. Several of these have attended graduate school and have not returned to K-12 teaching in time to complete their commitment. This finding that 10 Phase I scholars are not pursuing a teaching career has led to a more careful selection strategy where motivation to teach is accorded much greater weighting in the scholar selection rubric.

Overall, recruitment for the traditional secondary mathematics channels proved to be very difficult and has resulted in the creation of a new degree option of multi-disciplinary studies with a concentration in secondary mathematics, which was approved to begin in 2019. This degree pathway is the focus of the new Noyce award also beginning in 2019.

The tracking of scholarship holders has resulted in a careful review of the contracts signed by scholars. This is a legal document approved in 2009 by university lawyers. However, it lacked details on tracking and repayment and an updated version will be developed for the new Noyce award.
